summary: Email chain between FBI personnel discussing the processing status of digital evidence in the Epstein case, including items seized from New York City and the US Virgin Islands. The correspondence details completed and outstanding forensic analysis of computers, hard drives, and other devices, with plans to deliver processed documents to the SDNY for import into the Relativity review platform.

persons.name: Steve
persons.role: NY CART Coordinator Senior Forensic Examiner
persons.context: Author of email providing status update on digital evidence processing for the Epstein case, detailing items from NYC and USVI.

events.title: Epstein Evidence Status Update
events.description: Email exchange regarding the processing status of digital evidence in the Epstein case, noting 72 total items (32 from NYC, 40 from USVI) with 9 items outstanding.

events.title: Confirmation of Evidence Status
events.description: Follow-up email confirming the status of digital evidence processing and readiness to deliver documents to SDNY for import into Relativity.

keyFacts: There were 72 total digital evidence items in the Epstein case: 32 from New York City and 40 from the US Virgin Islands.
As of July 2020, 63 items had been processed, with 9 items outstanding requiring further forensic work (SSD from DVR, two Macs needing blacklight run, and RAID arrays needing rebuilding).
Processed documents were ready to be delivered to the SDNY for import into the Relativity review platform.
The email notes that some items were collected in error, including duplicate hard drives and non-evidentiary items like software install CDs.
